results.abstract: NASA officials say space shuttle fleet, grounded since mid-June because of minuscule fuel-line cracks, shoud be flying again by end of September, news conference; cite plan to weld and polish cracks (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Repairs Will Be Quick, NASA Says

results.snippet: The nation's space shuttle fleet, grounded since mid-June because of minuscule fuel-line cracks, should be flying again by the end of next month, NASA officials said today.    Ronald Dittemore, the space agency's shuttle program manager, said...
results.lead_paragraph: The nation's space shuttle fleet, grounded since mid-June because of minuscule fuel-line cracks, should be flying again by the end of next month, NASA officials said today. Ronald Dittemore, the space agency's shuttle program manager, said officials had approved a plan to weld and polish the hairline cracks found in metal fuel-pipe liners on all four shuttles. Repairs will begin next week on the Atlantis, which has three cracks in its hydrogen fuel piping, followed shortly by fixes of two fissures found in the Endeavour.

results.abstract: Article on New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg's decision not to include any original oratory in city's daylong observance of Sept 11 terrorist attacks; says while it will avoid politicizing event, it also becomes impossible to achieve great inspiration from carnage of one year ago; plans for observing day reviewed; photo (M)

headline.main: The Silence of the Historic Present; Sept. 11 Leaves Speakers at a Loss for Their Own Words

results.snippet: In the beginning was the absence of words.    No words could express the horror of Sept. 11, 2001, it was said again and again. No words could soothe the souls of the living or the dead. No words could express what the city had experienced; no words...
results.lead_paragraph: In the beginning was the absence of words. No words could express the horror of Sept. 11, 2001, it was said again and again. No words could soothe the souls of the living or the dead. No words could express what the city had experienced; no words could convey the collective sorrow. On such a day, in such a time, words would not do.

results.abstract: Possessed column on Vogue accessories director Michelle Sanders, who says this season's accessory is coral; photo (M)

headline.main: Coral Holds the Heart Of One Who Wants Not

results.snippet: MATTEL may have endowed Barbie with almost every vocation, the better to inspire a girl to think outside the box: astronaut, Olympic medalist, white-collar criminal. But if the doll maker wanted to appeal to grown-ups, one harbors a suspicion that it...
results.lead_paragraph: MATTEL may have endowed Barbie with almost every vocation, the better to inspire a girl to think outside the box: astronaut, Olympic medalist, white-collar criminal. But if the doll maker wanted to appeal to grown-ups, one harbors a suspicion that it would do well to pattern a Barbie on Michelle Sanders. The accessories director of Vogue, Ms. Sanders has unparalleled access to all the shoes, bags and jewelry a woman could ever -- but ever -- want. And not just any old shoe or belt. An important shoe. An important belt. The shoe for this season. The bag from next. (When Sarah Jessica Parker's character on ''Sex and the City'' made a guerrilla sortie into the Vogue fashion closet last season, even she had to try on ''the shoe.'')

results.abstract: Russian Space Agency suspends space-flight training of 'N Sync singer Lance Bass because financial backers missed payment deadline; Bass has been training for Soyuz rocket trip to International Space Station in October; David Krieff, who is organizing Bass's sponsorship, blames Russian bureaucracy for delay (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 'N Sync Singer Grounded

results.snippet: The Russian Space Agency said it had suspended space-flight training Lance Bass of the band 'N Sync because his financial backers had missed a payment deadline. Mr. Bass, 23, has been training since July at the Star City astronaut center outside...
results.lead_paragraph: The Russian Space Agency said it had suspended space-flight training Lance Bass of the band 'N Sync because his financial backers had missed a payment deadline. Mr. Bass, 23, has been training since July at the Star City astronaut center outside Moscow for a Soyuz rocket trip to the International Space Station in October. David Krieff, the Los Angeles television producer who is organizing sponsorship for Mr. Bass's $20 million spacefare, has blamed Russian bureaucracy and paperwork problems for the delay.

results.abstract: Lisa Eisner-Roman Alonso interview with Pierre Cardin at his science-fictional retreat on French Riviera; photos (special section, Fashions of The Times) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)
results.snippet: Pierre Cardin is a branding visionary. For more than 30 years he has been putting his stamp on everything and the kitchen sink -- luggage, linens, sardines, calculators, airplanes, cigarettes, hair dryers, pots and pans, cars, kitchens, liquor,...

byline.original: By Lisa Eisner and Román Alonso

results.lead_paragraph: Pierre Cardin is a branding visionary. For more than 30 years he has been putting his stamp on everything and the kitchen sink -- luggage, linens, sardines, calculators, airplanes, cigarettes, hair dryers, pots and pans, cars, kitchens, liquor, campers, skis, floor coverings, mattresses, collapsible bicycles, bathrooms, wallpaper, chocolates, alarm clocks and ice buckets. Today, more than 800 products bearing his name are sold in more than 140 countries. The business brings in a reported $1 billion a year, and Cardin, who just turned 80, is still the captain of his ship, making every deal himself. In 1959, he shocked the fashion world by presenting his first licensed ready-to-wear collection at the Paris department store Printemps. Cardin had ''sold out.'' He had come from the rarefied world of couture, working at Paquin, Schiaparelli and Christian Dior. Suddenly he was putting his name on clothing being sold off the rack. Today, with designer names splattered on everything, it's impossible to imagine that it wasn't always like this. Cardin saw the future before anyone else.

results.abstract: Profile of John Ashe, ambassador of Antigua and Barbuda at United Nations' World Summit on Sustainable Development in Johannesburg and chairman of meeting's trade and finance committee; he acknowledges that there will be tough negotiations between rich and poor nations on how to reduce poverty while preserving environment, but he says any movement at all in debate is progress; photo (M)

headline.main: U.N. Diplomat Seeks Miracle: Bring Together Rich and Poor

results.snippet: The big man in pinstripes walks into the convention center here and the diplomats take notice. The Japanese delegation asks for a few minutes of his time. South African officials whisper in his ear. In their offices nearby, senior American officials...
results.lead_paragraph: The big man in pinstripes walks into the convention center here and the diplomats take notice. The Japanese delegation asks for a few minutes of his time. South African officials whisper in his ear. In their offices nearby, senior American officials praise his leadership. The unlikely celebrity, who has a cellphone glued to his ear, chuckles at all the fuss.

results.abstract: Lance Bass of rock group 'N Sync is being embraced by National Aeronautics and Space Administration as public relations booster, although his sponsors have yet to put down $20 million he needs for his ticket as world's third space tourist; after welcoming Bass to Johnson Space Center in Houston to learn protocols for visiting International Space Station, NASA begins putting him to work as ambassador to the young, role he wholeheartedly embraces; photo (M)

headline.main: NASA Changes Its Tune on Space Tourists: This One Rocks

results.snippet: Although his sponsors have yet to put down the $20 million he needs for his ticket as the world's third space tourist, Lance Bass of 'N Sync is being embraced by NASA as a way to attract a new generation of space explorers.    Mr. Bass, 23, would be...
results.lead_paragraph: Although his sponsors have yet to put down the $20 million he needs for his ticket as the world's third space tourist, Lance Bass of 'N Sync is being embraced by NASA as a way to attract a new generation of space explorers. Mr. Bass, 23, would be the youngest and presumably most squeal-inducing person to travel into space, as a guest of Russia on a Soyuz flight to the International Space Station in October.
